tossups.answer: iPhone [accept answers like the first–generation iPhone; do not accept or prompt on "iPad"] (Merchant’s book is The One Device.)

answers: the experiments could be replicated [accept replication crisis or other word forms; accept reproducibility crisis or word forms; accept equivalents]
registered reports [accept pre-registration or word forms]

ESP [or extrasensory perception; or psi; accept sixth sense; accept telepathy; accept paranormal activity; accept premonition or precognition or clairvoyance or retrocausation; accept parapsychology; prompt on being psychic or anomalous phenomena; accept "Feeling the Future: Experimental Evidence for Anomalous Retroactive Influences on Cognition and Affect"]
parts: Identify this outcome that Nosek had earlier found was not possible for some 64% of psychology experiments, causing a namesake "crisis."

This peer review format might help fix the replication crisis by limiting p-hacking and HARKing. Nature Human Behavior has adopted this format, in which journals accept stage-one protocols before researchers submit results.

Many psychologists trace widespread awareness of the replication crisis to a 2011 paper by Daryl Bem that reported statistical evidence of this phenomenon while apparently using standard methodology. Ganzfeld experiments and Zener cards test this general phenomenon.

answers: Tallinn
cruise ships [or cruise ferries or cruise boats; prompt on boats or other answers without "cruise"]
Vikings [or Vikingers; or specific kinds of Vikings; prompt on Scandinavians or Northmen or other non-specific answers]
parts: Name this city that hosts the Black Nights Film Festival, as well as a dance festival held in the Kalev Football Club's stadium concurrent with its famed Song Festival.

In 1994, hundreds died when one of these objects called the MS Estonia failed to reach Stockholm from Tallinn. These luxury vehicles now offer themed experiences based on common "affinities" like Jonathan Coulton, The Nation magazine, and Disney.
A Swiss company named for these people helped popularize river cruises. A traveling museum exhibit named for these people displays a "gripping-beast" brooch.

answers: HIV-positive people [or people suffering from HIV or people suffering from AIDS or poz people]
circumcision [accept female circumcision or female genital mutilation or female genital cutting or FGM]

Anglican Church [accept Episcopal Church; accept more specific answers like the Anglican Church of Uganda; prompt on the church or Christianity; do not accept or prompt on "Catholic Church"] (Robinson is openly gay.)
parts: Identify these much-stigmatized people. In the US, the case Harrison v. Esper is challenging a DoD ban on these people serving on active duty.

Several African countries have encouraged this practice in men to reduce HIV infection risk. This practice sometimes shares its name with a procedure that some African cultures carry out on women, causing cysts and chronic pain.

Uganda's Gideon Byamugisha was awarded the Niwano Peace Prize for becoming the first member of this organization to come out as HIV-positive. In 2003, this organization fractured between supporters and opponents of Gene Robinson.

answers: hauntology [or hantologie; prompt on haunting or ghosts or phantoms or phantasms or similar answers; accept "Post-Soviet Hauntology: Cultural Memory of the Soviet Terror"]

spectres [or Gespenster; accept the spectre of communism or das Gespenst des Kommunismus; accept Specters of Marx: The State of the Debt, the Work of Mourning and the New International or Spectres de Marx: l'état de la dette, le travail du deuil et la nouvelle Internationale]
Afrofuturism [accept "Black to the Future"; accept Afropessimism; accept word forms; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Identify this punning term coined by Jacques Derrida for a supernatural phenomenon whose repetition makes it both "first time" and "last time." The 1993 passage introducing this concept quotes heavily from the opening of Hamlet and notes Marx's love of Shakespeare.
Derrida formulated hauntology in a book named for these things "of Marx." Marx himself wrote that one of these spooky entities was "haunting Europe."

Mark Fisher, a.k.a. "k-punk," tied hauntology to this concept in "The Metaphysics of Crackle." Interviews with Greg Tate and Tricia Rose inspired Mark Dery's 1994 essay coining this term, which Frank B. Wilderson III modified with "pessimism."

answers: John Updike [or John Hoyer Updike]
thesaurus [accept Roget’s Thesaurus; do not accept or prompt on “dictionary”] (Lockwood quipped, "one feels oddly proud, after all, of a penis that has learned to read.")
James Wood [or James Douglas Graham Wood]
parts: Identify this author whose late-career work includes the 2006 novel Terrorist and the novella Rabbit Remembered.

In a 1997 review, David Foster Wallace infamously dismissed Updike as "just a penis with a [one of these things]." Joshua Kendell’s biography The Man Who Made Lists is about the creator of the most famous example of these things.
This literary critic for The New Yorker and Harvard professor declared Updike unreadable for the misogyny in his writing. His own novels include 2018's Upstate.

answers: cremations [prompt on disposing a dead body or similar; accept direct cremation]
New Zealand [or Aotearoa]
"Ask a Mortician"
parts: Name this practice that has risen dramatically in recent years. A process that uses alkaline hydrolysis is often billed as a "green" or "flameless" alternative to this practice.
A Coffin Club founded on this country's North Island kicked off a trend for people building their own coffins prior to death. 185 people died in the 2011 earthquake in its city of Christchurch.
Caitlin Doughty hosts this popular web series, which examines "iconic corpses" like Vladimir Lenin and answers questions like what happens to breast implants in corpses.

answers: Julie Taymor (The project was Spider-Man: Turn off the Dark.)
Jessye Norman
The Lion King
parts: Name this director whose 2005 production of Mozart's The Magic Flute inaugurated PBS's series Great Performances at the Met. A non-opera project directed by this woman became notorious for the many injuries that its actors, such as Natalie Mendoza, sustained during stunt rehearsals.

Taymor's first opera production, which was of Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex, starred this singer as Jocasta. Before her 2019 death, this African-American soprano was well-known for her recordings of Richard Strauss, particularly his Four Last Songs.
Taymor won two Tony Awards for her blockbuster Broadway adaptation of this Disney film. Beyoncé starred in its 2019 remake.

answers: Ben Lerner [or Benjamin S. Lerner] (The second novel is 10:04.)
poetry [accept The Hatred of Poetry; accept Poetry Magazine]
John Ashbery [or John Lawrence Ashbery]
parts: Identify this American author of Leaving the Atocha Station whose 2014 metafictional novel takes its title from a plot element in Back to the Future.

In a book-length essay titled for this genre, Lerner calls all works in this genre "a record of failure." John Barr controversially called for "something new" in this genre in a 2006 essay in a magazine also named for it.
Leaving the Atocha Station takes its title from this poet, the subject of Karin Roffman's 2017 biography The Songs We Know Best. He wrote Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror.

answers: RVs [or Recreational Vehicles; prompt on vehicles]
vans [or microvans; or minivans]
Airstream [prompt on Thor Industries]
parts: Identify these things made by companies such as East to West. Walmart officially allows these things to stay overnight on their property, but does not provide electricity for them.

Instagram has made it possible for photogenic people to go around the country in these vehicles. "Micro" examples of these vehicles such as the Subaru Sambar have more nostalgic chic than "mini" ones like the Honda Odyssey.
This company manufactured NASA's Astrovan. As VP, Joe Biden flew on a C-17 equipped with one of this company's nostalgic travel trailers inside.

answers: Federico Fellini [accept Fellini: I'm a Born Liar]
Alejandro Jodorowsky ("ho-dor-OFF–skee") [or Alejandro "Alexandro" Jodorowsky Prullansky; accept Jodorowsky's Dune; prompt on Jodo]
Guy Maddin
parts: This director's film Amarcord is a semi-autobiographical account of his own childhood in Fascist Italy. A 2002 documentary by Damian Pettigrew subtitled "I'm a Born Liar" records the final confessions of this filmmaker of La dolce vita ("lah DOHL-chay VEE-tah").
This Chilean-French filmmaker wrote a fictionalized account of his childhood titled The Dance of Reality. A 2013 documentary by Frank Pavich examined his failed attempt to make a Dune adaptation.

This Canadian director drew on his childhood in the title city to create the "docu-fantasia" My Winnipeg. This director evokes the aesthetic of the silent era with frequent iris shots and crazy camera angles in films like Keyhole.

answers: the Green Zone [accept International Zone of Baghdad; prompt on Baghdad; accept al-minṭaqah al-ḫaḍrā]
Robert D. Kaplan [or Robert David Kaplan]
Yemen [or Republic of Yemen; or al-Jumhūrīyah al-Yamanīyah; or Yemeni Republic; accept Yemeni Civil War]
parts: Name this location of a CPA where recruited workers were asked their opinions on Roe v. Wade. This place provides the title of Rajiv Chandrasekaran's book Imperial Life in the Emerald City.

This author visited the Green Zone for his book Imperial Grunts. He discussed the influence of historical contingency on world affairs in The Revenge of Geography, and first gained fame with his 1994 article "The Coming Anarchy."

Kaplan claimed that this country is a "segmentary" society that is naturally difficult to govern. A cholera epidemic in Houthi-controlled parts of this country has exacerbated suffering from its civil war.

answers: Nicaragua [or Republic of Nicaragua; or República de Nicaragua]
a canal between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans [or a ship canal]
Tlatelolco massacre
parts: Name this country where protesters have uprooted the expensive Trees of Life planted by its Vice President and First Lady, Rosario Murillo.

Daniel Ortega's son Laureano headed a failed plan to build one of these infrastructure projects in Nicaragua with Chinese funds. An expansion for another of these projects completed in 2016 added support for vehicles classified as "New Panamax."

Nicaraguan Vice President Sergio Ramírez won the Cervantes Prize in 2017. Another winner, Elena Poniatowska, gained fame for covering this 1968 massacre of students in Mexico's Plaza de las Tres Culturas.

answers: the supermassive black hole photograph [accept equivalents such as the image of a supermassive black hole; prompt on black holes or other nonspecific answers]
very long baseline interferometry [or VLBI; prompt on astronomical interferometry or using an astronomical interferometer; accept aperture synthesis]
radio waves [accept radio astronomy]
parts: Identify this result obtained in spring 2019 by over 200 researchers at MIT, Harvard, and Radboud University. Media coverage of this feat focused on computer scientist Katie Bouman.

The black hole photo was taken by using this technique to synchronize an array of telescopes into a giant virtual telescope. This technique measures the time difference between signals emitted by quasars arriving at different telescopes.
Quasars and other VLBI sources emit this type of electromagnetic radiation, which has a wavelength longer than infrared, allowing it to propagate through antennas like microwaves.

answers: Babri Masjid [or Babri Mosque]
Bharatiya Janata Party [or BJP; or Indian People's Party]
Nathuram Godse (“nuh–THOO–ram GOD–say”) [or Nathuram Vinayak Godse] (Godse assassinated Mahatma Gandhi.)
parts: Identify this mosque in Ayodhya (“uh-YODE-yuh”) that was destroyed in 1992. In the violent aftermath of the teardown, some two thousand people were killed.
One of the main advocates of "liberating" the mosque from Muslims was Lal Krishna Advani, a member of this Indian political party. It's not the RSS, but Narendra Modi leads this party.

After coming to power, the BJP attempted to build a temple devoted to this man in Sitapur and to honor him each January 30th on "Bravery Day." An annual gathering each November 15th in Pune (“POO-nay”) honors this man's blood-stained shirt.

answers: Sex at Dawn [or Sex at Dawn: How We Mate, Why We Stray, and What It Means for Modern Relationships] (The Lynn Saxon book is called Sex at Dusk.)
evolutionary psychology [accept evo psych; prompt on partial answers; prompt on sexual evolution]
moralizing high gods [or deities; accept supernatural agents; accept equivalents]
parts: Name this book by Christopher Ryan and Cacilda Jethá which argues that prehistoric humans resembled bonobos by avoiding warfare and forming "socio-erotic exchanges" with multiple sexual partners.
Sex at Dawn critiques the "standard narrative" of this two-word field, which attempts to identify the adaptive origins of human behavior but often develops untestable hypotheses.

Evolutionary psychologist Candace Alcorta argued that belief in these entities is adaptive. A 2019 Nature paper suggested that complex societies preceded "moralizing" examples of these entities like Ahura Mazda.

answers: Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 [or RFRA]
Native Americans [or American Indians; or indigenous people; or First Nations; accept specific Native peoples]
Plowshares movement
parts: Identify this legislation unanimously passed by Congress in 1993. This law effectively re-instated the Sherbert Test that requires applying strict scrutiny when judging the Free Exercise Clause.
The RFRA ("RIFF-ra") was passed after a court ruled that this general class of people could not use ritualistic peyote. A 1990 law protects the graves of these people and their ancestors.

Members of this pacifist movement co-founded by the Berrigans argued that the RFRA protected them from imprisonment after illegally entering Kings Bay Naval Submarine Base in 2018 to protest nuclear weapons.

answers: air conditioning [or AC; or refrigeration or cooling; prompt on HVAC systems]
Kigali [accept Kigali Amendment]
Lee Kuan Yew
parts: Identify this technology widely used in outdoor spaces in Qatar. Due to the fluorinated gases produced from this tech, it is a significant contributor to climate change.
A 2016 amendment to the Montreal Protocol named for this city establishes a timetable for phasing out toxic refrigerant gases. Cyprien Ntaryamira was killed near this capital city's airport.

In a 2009 interview with New Perspectives Quarterly, this leader credited air conditioning and "multicultural tolerance" as the keys to his country's success. His country's GDP increased by 100 times between 1960 and 2011.

answers: contemporary art market [or fine art; anti-prompt (ask "can you be less specific?") on more specific answers like painting or sculpture]
Nathaniel Kahn (His father was Louis Kahn.)
Larry Gagosian ("ga-GO-zee-in") [or Lawrence Gilbert Gagosian]
parts: Identify this market. Michael Shnayerson's ("SHNAY-er-son’s") book Boom tracks rising prices in "Modern" and "Contemporary" offerings in this market at auction firms like Christie's.

This director examined the contemporary art market in his 2018 HBO film, The Price of Everything. His film My Architect is about his Estonian-American father, the designer of the Salk Institute and the Parliament building in Dhaka.

Shnayerson's book includes a chapter on a lawsuit between this art dealer and Ronald Perelman over an unfinished Jeff Koons piece. Jean Nouvel designed this man's Le Bourget gallery in Paris, his company's 12th such location.

answers: recruited student-athletes [accept college athletes]
University of Southern California [or USC; or Southern Cal]

parts: Identify these people whose scholarships have been called an affirmative-action program for white men.

Jovan Vavic ("YO-vahn VA-vich"), the water polo coach at this school, was accused of taking bribes in the Operation Varsity Blues scandal. Athletes who attended this university have won 288 Olympic medals, the most from any school.

A 2019 piece in The Daily Princetonian concluded that a Connecticut region of this name had the highest concentration of Ivy League athletes in the world. Surfers have long flocked to beaches like The Spit and South Straddie in an Australian city of this name.

answers: Chicago [accept nicknames like "the Windy City"]
Cedar Rapids, Iowa
giant panda bears [or Ailuropoda melanoleuca; or dàxióngmāo; prompt on bears or carnivores]
parts: The trend began when this city erected some 334 fiberglass bulls in the late 1990s. This city's other public art includes Anish Kapoor's Cloud Gate.
This city's response to the CowParade project was "Overalls All Over." Its art museum has the world's largest collection of paintings by Grant Wood, including Wood's painting Young Corn.

In the early 2000s, Washington, D.C. was dotted with statues of donkeys, elephants, and these other animals. The Smithsonian's website operates two cameras to track the movement of some of these animals.
